data.creator: RALDE team
data.text_p1: This virtual practical aims to teach you the basics of cell culture. It is composed of a set of interactive elements that will introduce you to the different steps and knowledge required to master this field of expertise.
data.text_p2: You will have to interact with the different components of this VP

menu_items.title: Exploring the cell culture lab & Preparing the cell culture room/conditions

data.h3: Please watch the video before continuing the practical

data.text_p1: Please read the contents of the following resources

links.resource_title: Addgene: 10 tips for mammalian cell culture
Technology Network: How to prevent cell culture contamination ?
Technology Network: How To Prevent Cell Culture Contamination ? (Infographic)

data.text_p1: Click on the marker to explore the different items of a cell culture laboratory

hotSpots.modal_text: The box contains gloves in all sizes
Keep the lid closed. Clean rotor and chamber regularly

Warm water is the ideal medium for all kinds of contaminants. In order to bring the media and other components to the ideal temperature for your cells, you will typically place the non-sterile vessels into a water bath. You will have to ensure that the caps of the vessels are not in contact with the water at any time. Bacteria and other contaminants might remain here and subsequently contaminate the inside of the vessel once it is opened. Just like the CO2 incubator, a water bath requires a regular disinfection routine. You must ensure that the water bath is emptied completely and disinfected prior to the addition of fresh water. Finally, the appropriate amounts of fungicide and bactericide should be added to the fresh water. A thermo block is a good alternative to the classic water bath - it is easier to clean and it works without water

A white coat, also known as a laboratory coat or lab coat, is a knee-length overcoat or smock worn by professionals in the medical field or by those involved in laboratory work. The coat protects their street clothes and also serves as a simple uniform. The garment is made from white or light-colored cotton, linen, or cotton polyester blend, allowing it to be washed at high temperature and making it easy to see if it is clean.

The degree of confluence, as well as appearance and morphology of the cells, have to be checked regularly via microscopy. When placing your cell culture consumables under the microscope, you must ensure that you are not opening the dish, flask or plate accidentally. Keep the time under the microscope as short as possible in order to avoid any unnecessary cooling of the cells. To achieve this, you should prepare the working area prior to removing the cells from the CO2 incubator

The nitrogen tank is used to store cell strains for long-term use. Please use appropriate personal protective equipment when handling liquid nitrogen (cold-resistant gloves, face shield, lab coat or protective apron)

The environmental conditions in a CO2 incubator are not only perfect for growing your cells, but they are also perfect for the growth of bacterial cells and fungi. Therefore, regular disinfection of the incubator is critical for the protection of your cells. The incubator should be easy to clean, which can be accomplished by a racking system which is easy to disassemble. The water in the incubator needs to be changed regularly. Make sure that you empty the water tray completely and disinfect it before you fill it with fresh sterile water. An automatic disinfection mode can help maintain sterility, especially if the chamber is not free of seams and welds.
The refrigerator and the freezer are used to store culture media bottles, trypsin, and some antibiotics. It is not the place to store cells.

The principles of working in a cell culture lab become even more relevant when working in a biosafety cabinet. In general, the cabinet should be as empty as possible. Do not place or store any items in the cabinet that are not necessary for your current working procedure and do not overload it with too many dishes, plates, flasks, etc. at one time. Before starting your work you should empty the entire work area and disinfect it. Do not simply spray your disinfection solution on everything, but instead wipe the solution across the entire surface of the cabinet. Then apply the same procedure to every item that you will place into the cabinet. A working direction from 'clean' to 'dirty' should be established at this time: if you are right-handed, you might start at the left side with placing your dishes, flasks or plates and all clean, new materials such as pipette tips. In the center is your working area where you will open your consumables and change the media. The right end of the cabinet will be your designated waste area with a container for used tips, etc.

data.text_p1: Start the flow cabinet (answers with picture, several responses required)
data.badAnswerText: Bad answer, please re-read the provided information or re-watch the film
data.partialAnswerText: Please think about the flow and the window
data.goodAnswerText: Good job: A full flow will protect cells from external contaminations and opening 1/3rd the window will allow enough air to enter the system without disturbing the laminar flow.

data.text_p1: Switch on UV-lamp for

choices.answer: 5-10 minutes
15-30 minutes
40-60 minutes
choices.bad_answer_special_text: Leaving them on for longer can lead to the breakdown of any plastics in the hood, as well as affect people working in the area. Using a UV light over an hour or overnight is massive overkill

choices.answer: overnight
choices.bad_answer_special_text: Leaving them on for longer can lead to the breakdown of any plastics in the hood, as well as affect people working in the area. Using a UV light over an hour or overnight is massive overkill

data.goodAnswerText: Explanation: UV sterilizers need only be on for 15-30 minutes at most in cell culture hoods, depending on the intensity of the UV-lamp. This is the time needed to kill of the bacteria and inactivate spore forming organisms present in the environment. Some laboratories switch on the UV between users, while others only at the start and/or the end of the day. Longer UV light times will not improve cabinet disinfection in routine cell culture cabinets.

data.text_p1: Put water bath at ___°C and put in the cell culture medium and buffer solutions

choices.bad_answer_special_text: Bad answer, please re-read the provided information or re-watch the film. High temperatures may result in cell death
Bad answer, please re-read the provided information or re-watch the film. High temperatures may result in cell death
Bad answer, please re-read the provided information or re-watch the film. High temperatures may result in cell death
Bad answer, please re-read the provided information or re-watch the film. High temperatures may result in cell death

data.goodAnswerText: Explanation: human and mammalian cell lines should be kept at 37°C for optimal growth, thus it is convenient that all solutions that are in contact with them are around this temperature. Overheating them can cause serious damage and can lead to cell death.

data.text_p1: Just before starting: Wipe the surface area with a tissue with ...

choices.answer: Water with detergent
choices.bad_answer_special_text: Please re-read the provided information or re-watch the film

choices.answer: 70% ethanol
100% ethanol
choices.bad_answer_special_text: 100% ethanol coagulates membrane proteins so fast that the contaminants get inactive but do not die

data.badAnswerText: Bad answer : please reread your notes
data.goodAnswerText: 70% ethanol penetrates cell membranes slower so that it can really reach the center of the contaminants and kill them. 100% ethanol coagulates membrane proteins so fast that the contaminants get inactive but do not die.

data.text_p1: To spray the ethanol it is best to use

choices.answer: Spray bottle
choices.bad_answer_special_text: Spray bottles were used a lot in the past and are still in use, but for health safety measures are advised against. The aerosols that are create with spray bottles can be inhaled by the user.

choices.answer: Glass bottle with big opening
choices.bad_answer_special_text: Please check the guide the provided information or re-watch the film. Think about a way to deliver the correct amount of ethanol in a safe way.

choices.answer: Squeeze bottle

data.badAnswerText: Bad answer : Bad answer: Please check the guide the provided information or re-watch the film. Think about a way to deliver the correct amount of ethanol in a safe way.
data.goodAnswerText: Explanation: Spray bottles were used a lot in the past and are still in use, but for health safety measures are advised against. The aerosols that are created with spray bottles can be inhaled by the user. So currently squeeze bottles are the best to use.

data.text_p1: Select the correct position to work in the flow cabinet

choices.bad_answer_special_text: Please re-read the guidelines or re-watch the instruction film
Please re-read the guidelines or re-watch the instruction film
Please re-read the guidelines or re-watch the instruction film
Please re-read the guidelines or re-watch the instruction film
Please re-read the guidelines or re-watch the instruction film

data.badAnswerText: Please re-read the guidelines or re-watch the instruction film
data.goodAnswerText: Walls and objects disturb the laminar flow, therefore the best place to work is the middle of the cabinet. Moreover, the front part of the cabinet is the part with the highest contamination risk since it is the closest to the end of the laminar flow and is easily disturbed by slight movements.

data.text_p1: Select the ideal state of the flow

choices.bad_answer_special_text: Having the flow cabinet full of things will disturb the flow of the air and thus disrupt the sterile environment.

data.badAnswerText: Having the flow cabinet full of things will disturb the flow of the air and thus disrupt the sterile environment.
data.goodAnswerText: Only put in the flow cabinet what you need at one moment: tips, pipettes, tubes or plates. Please remember you need to disinfect all items with 70% ethanol before placing them in the flow cabinet. Do not let old plates linger on the side or do not overload with too many tip boxes, etc. Having the flow cabinet full of things will disturb the flow of the air and thus disrupt the sterile environment.

data.text_p1: The incubator for growing the cells should be kept at:

choices.answer: 37° C and 5% CO₂
choices.bad_answer_special_text: Bad answer : Please check the guide the provided information or re-watch the film

choices.answer: 37° C and 10% CO₂
choices.bad_answer_special_text: Bad answer : Please check the guide the provided information or re-watch the film

choices.answer: 45° C and 5% CO₂
choices.bad_answer_special_text: Bad answer : Please check the guide the provided information or re-watch the film

choices.answer: 45° C and 10% CO₂
choices.bad_answer_special_text: Bad answer : Please check the guide the provided information or re-watch the film

data.goodAnswerText: human and mammalian cell lines should be kept at 37ºC for optimal growth, 5% CO2 is needed to buffer the system to ensure that the normal physiological pH is maintained for optimum cell growth

data.text_p1: Please read the contents of the following resources as a preparation

links.resource_title: Technology Network : Which cell media is right for you?

imgs_texts.title: Adherent cells
imgs_texts.text: Adherent cells are cells which must be attached to a surface to grow. They are commonly used in laboratory environments. The origin of this type of cells is usually solid tissues.

imgs_texts.title: Cells in suspension
imgs_texts.text: A cell suspension or suspension culture is a type of cell culture in which single cells or small aggregates of cells are allowed to function and multiply in an agitated growth medium, thus forming a suspension. This type of cells is usually originate from blood.

data.text_p1: What is the correct spot to prepare the medium?

markers.title: Bench
markers.answer_text: Cell culture medium could not be prepared in the bench since it is not an sterile environment.

markers.title: flow cabinet
markers.answer_text: Cell culture medium should indeed be prepared in a sterile environment. Working under a flow cabinet helps you to maintain the sterility of your cell cultures

data.text_p1: The next section and questions are about:
Prepare everything you need for thawing the cells. More than one answer is correct
data.badAnswerText: Bad answer: Please check ATTC instructions again
data.goodAnswerText: Cell thawing should be fast, everything that will be needed should already be inside the cabinet. You’ll need warm medium and a tube to remove the cryoprotectant, the micropipette to transfer the cells and the medium, and the cell culture flask. Besides, everything that will enter the cabinet will need to be first cleaned with ethanol.

answers.text: Warm the complete medium in the water bath and put it in the flow cabinet
Place a sterile tube in a rack inside the cabinet
Place micropipette and pipette tips inside the cabinet
Place FBS in the water bath
Place a sterile cell culture flask in the flow cabinet
Place sterile serological pipettes and pipettor in the flow cabinet

data.text_p1: Where to get the cells?

markers.title: Liquid nitrogen tank
markers.answer_text: Temperatures warmer than 135ºC result in cell death and increase contamination risk. Apart from liquid nitrogen tanks, also -135ºC freezers exist and can be used.

markers.title: Lab closet
markers.answer_text: Lab closet is not suitable for cells storage

markers.title: Incubator
markers.answer_text: Incubator is not suitable for long-term storage of cells

markers.title: fridge
markers.answer_text: Fridge is not the place to store cells

markers.title: -20°C freezer
markers.answer_text: Freezer is not the place to store cells

data.text_p1: What do you need to wear in order to take the cells? More than one answer may be correct
data.badAnswerText: Bad answer, please re-read your notes
data.goodAnswerText: Liquid Nitrogen is dangerous and may burn your skin if little drops reach you

markers.title: Bench

markers.title: Water bath
markers.answer_text: Fast thawing at 37°C will result in greater cell viability

markers.title: Incubator

data.text_p1: How to process thawed cells?

choices.answer: Spin at 150-300 g for 5 min to remove freezing medium and dilute 10 x in cell culture medium
choices.bad_answer_special_text: Bad answer : please reread your notes

choices.answer: Quick spin at 13000xg for 1min to remove freezing medium
choices.bad_answer_special_text: Bad answer : please reread your notes

choices.answer: Dilute 10x in cell culture medium and centrifuge  to remove freezing medium(5 min, 150-300 g, RT)

data.badAnswerText: Bad answer : please reread your notes
data.goodAnswerText: Dilute first the cryoprotectant so that is no longer toxic and then spin down in order to get rid of it.

data.text_p1: The next section and questions are about:
Select the correct culture material to start a culture from thawed adherent cell
data.badAnswerText: Bad answer, please reread your notes
data.goodAnswerText: Cells are maintained in culture flasks. Cryotubes normally contain low number of cells so a T25 would keep cells closer to each other avoiding low density-related stress.

choices.answer: T25 for adherent cells and cells in suspension

data.badAnswerText: The type of medium is cell-line specific so it is sufficient to just write the cell type, cell concentration is not necessary for adherent cell maintenance, volume of medium is the same for every flask size (i.e., 5 mL for T25)
data.goodAnswerText: Good job

data.text_p1: Select the correct position of the cell culture flasks with adherent cells if the cap has no filter in it

choices.answer: Horizontal - cap closed
Horizontal - open cap for a quarter turn
Horizontal - fully opened cap
Vertical - cap closed
Vertical - open cap for a quarter turn
Vertical - fully opened cap

data.badAnswerText: Bad answer : please reread your notes
data.goodAnswerText: Caps without filter need to be a little open so that there is gas exchange between the cells and the incubator. The flask must be placed horizontal so that cell will attached to the treated surface of the flask.

data.text_p1: Prepare reagents for cryopreservation of A549 or HepG2 cells. Choose the most appropriate answer

Complete growth medium containing 10% FBS

choices.bad_answer_special_text: Bad answer: Please check the ATTC instructions

choices.bad_answer_special_text: Bad answer: Please check the ATTC instructions

data.badAnswerText: Bad answer: Please check the ATTC instructions
data.goodAnswerText: Cells can be frozen in FBS or medium but always with a cryoprotectant such as DMSO to remove water from the inside of the cells and prevent membrane rupture after freezing. Percentages greater than 10% DMSO may result in cell death

choices.answer: I can only count them under a microscope, automatic counting leads to too many errors
choices.bad_answer_special_text: Bad answer : please reread your notes

choices.answer: I can only count them with an automatic counter, manual counting leads to too many errors
choices.bad_answer_special_text: Bad answer : please reread your notes

choices.answer: Cells can be counted indistinctly under the microscope or with an automatic counter. The only difference is the price of the automatic chambers
choices.bad_answer_special_text: Bad answer : please reread your notes

choices.answer: Both methods are valid, as long as you maintain the method used through experiments of the same type

data.badAnswerText: Bad answer : please reread your notes
data.goodAnswerText: Cells can be frozen in FBS or medium but always with a cryoprotectant such as DMSO to remove water from the inside of the cells and prevent membrane rupture after freezing. Percentages greater than 10% DMSO may result in cell death

data.text_p1: What do you see when you use Trypan blue for cell counting?

choices.answer: Blue cells are the living ones
choices.bad_answer_special_text: Bad answer : please reread your notes

choices.answer: Blue cells are the dead ones
choices.bad_answer_special_text: Bad answer : please reread your notes

choices.answer: Blue cells have the membrane damaged.

data.badAnswerText: Bad answer : please reread your notes
data.goodAnswerText: Trypan blue can only enter the cells if the membrane is damaged. Therefore, although damaged membranes normally result in cell death, it is not fully correct to say that blue cells are dead since there may be a population that is just damaged but that may recover. Still it gives you a good estimation of the proportion of live/healthy cells.

data.text_p1: What would be the result of this counting?

choices.answer: 320.000 cells/mL
choices.bad_answer_special_text: Bad answer : please reread your notes or check your calculation

choices.answer: 260.000 cells/mL
170.000 cells/mL
choices.bad_answer_special_text: Bad answer : please reread your notes or check your calculation

data.badAnswerText: Bad answer : please reread your notes
data.goodAnswerText: The blue cell is damaged and should not be counted as a healthy one. Since there has been a 1:2 dilution with trypan blue, the scoring has to be multiplied by 2. (13 cells × 2 = 26 cells. 26 cells ×  10⁴ cells/mL = 260.000 cells/mL

data.text_p1: Which is the volume of cell suspension used per cryotube for freezing the cells?
data.badAnswerText: Bad answer : please reread your notes
data.goodAnswerText: Freezing 1 million of cells in a too small volume will make the solution too dense and this is disadvantageous for the cell viability.

data.text_p1: How to mix cells with freezing medium. Choose the most appropriate answer

choices.answer: First mix with plain medium and then gently add medium with 10% of DMSO while mixing
choices.bad_answer_special_text: Bad answer : please reread your notes

choices.answer: Prepare complete growth medium with 5-10% DMSO beforehand and then resuspend the pellet in it
Prepare growth medium with 40% FBS, 10% DMSO beforehand and then resuspend the pellet in it.
choices.bad_answer_special_text: Bad answer : please reread your notes

data.badAnswerText: Bad answer : please reread your notes
data.goodAnswerText: DMSO should not be added directly on top of the cells with medium since each drop of it will kill the cells it touches until it dissolves

data.text_p1: How to freeze the cells

answers.text: Place them at -80°C as quickly as possible
Slow freeze in polystyrene box (wall at least 1cm thick) in -20°C
Slow freeze in polystyrene box (wall at least 5mm thick) in -80°C
Slow freeze in polystyrene box (wall at least 1cm thick) in -80°C
Slow freeze in Mr Frosty container containing isopropanol

data.badAnswerText: Bad answer: not using a box or a box with too thin wall can damage the cells due to crystal formation
data.goodAnswerText: Isopropanol decreases 1ºC/hour after putting it in the freezer. Freezing in a Mr. Frosty results in a slow freezing procedure that increases cell surviving

data.text_p1: Once frozen, cells can be stored at ___°C for reculturing at later point

choices.bad_answer_special_text: Storing at -20°C is to warm to guarantee the viability of the cells, even for short term.
Bad answer: for short term storage -80°C can be OK but not for long term storage

data.badAnswerText: Bad answer : please reread your notes
data.goodAnswerText: Temperatures above -130ºC for long term storage may result in cell death

data.text_p1: Check cell confluency. At what confluency should you subculture your cells?

choices.bad_answer_special_text: Bad answer : please reread your notes
Bad answer : please reread your notes

data.badAnswerText: Bad answer : please reread your notes
data.goodAnswerText: Cells should be in an optimal state in order to undergo trypsinization (80% confluency). At higher densities, cells are stressed and their behaviour may change, they can even mutate.

data.text_p1: Which of these pictures represents 80% confluency? (answers with pictures)

choices.bad_answer_special_text: Bad answer : please reread your notes
Bad answer : please reread your notes
Bad answer : please reread your notes
Bad answer : please reread your notes

data.badAnswerText: Please re-read the guidelines or re-watch the instruction film
data.goodAnswerText: 100% confluence means that there is no more room for cells to grow, at this state they can only start dying.

data.text_p1: If cells are at 80% confluency a passage should be performed. How would you do it? Order all the steps you'd take. (All steps shown may not be necessary)
data.text_p2: reorder sentence and put non necessary steps in the trash zone
data.badAnswerText: Bad order : try again
data.goodAnswerText: Good job you can continue the practical

choices.answer: Remove the medium
Add 0.25% Trypsin (37ºC)
Add fresh medium (37ºC) into a T25 flask
Add PBS (37ºC) to the flask and wash the cell monolayer
Check if the cells are detached under the microscope
Collect the cells in a tube
If detached: add fresh medium (37ºC) on top of the trypsin
Place the cells in the incubator for 5-15 min
Place the flask with the cells in the incubator
Remove the PBS
Dilute the cells to the cell concentration needed for subcultivation
Take an aliquot to count
Add fresh medium (37ºC) in to a T75 flask
Prepare the new plates by labelling them with cell type, passage, date and initials
Subcultivate the cells in a ratio of 1:6 (if the total volume of trypsin stopped with complete medium is 6mL, you transfer 1mL to a new T25 plate)
Subcultivate the cells in a ratio of 1:6 (if the total volume of trypsin stopped with complete medium is 6mL, you transfer 2mL to a new T75 plate)

data.text_p1: How would you perform a passage if your cells are in 5 mL and you want to subculture them at 1:5 in a T75?

choices.answer: Add 5 mL medium to the cells, transfer 3 mL to a new T75 and add 10 mL to the new flask
Take the 5 mL of the flask and transfer them to a new T75. Then add 10 mL complete medium
Add 10 mL complete medium to the flask and transfer 3 mL to anew T75
Add 14 mL complete medium to a new T75 and transfer 1 mL from the original flask

data.badAnswerText: Bad answer : please re read your notes
data.goodAnswerText: Sudden acidity of the medium indicate the presence of more living organisms than just the cell line. The release of CO₂ increases in great proportion due to the respiration of the cells and the contaminants and it leads to an intense yellow color of the medium.

data.text_p1: Check the cells concentration by counting the cells; when the cells should be subcultured?

choices.answer: When the cell concentration is above 200.000 cells/mL
choices.bad_answer_special_text: Bad answer : Please check the ATTC instructions

choices.answer: When the cell concentration is above 500.000 cells/mL
choices.bad_answer_special_text: Bad answer : Please check the ATTC instructions

choices.answer: When the cell concentration is above 800.000 cells/mL
When the cell concentration is above 1.000.000 cells/mL
choices.bad_answer_special_text: Bad answer : Please check the ATTC instructions

data.badAnswerText: Bad answer : please reread your notes
data.goodAnswerText: Cells should be in an optimal state in order to be subcultured; at higher concentrations cells are stressed and their behaviour may change, they can even mutate. TK6 and THP-1 cells should be maintained between 2 x10⁵ and 1 X 10⁶ cells/mL

data.text_p1: If after counting cells are at a concentration above 800.000 cells/mL a subcultivation should be performed. Cultures can be maintained by addition or replacement of fresh medium. How would you do it by addition of fresh medium? Order all the steps you’d take. (All steps shown may not be necessary)
data.text_p2: reorder sentence and put non necessary steps in the trash zone
data.badAnswerText: Bad order : try again
data.goodAnswerText: Good job you can continue the practical

choices.answer: Add fresh medium to dilute the cell suspension to 2x10⁵ cells/mL in a certain volume
Remove the medium
Add 0.25% Trypsin (37ºC)
Collect the cells in a tube
Take an aliquote of the cell suspension with the required amount of cells and tranfer it to a new flask
Add fresh medium to dilute the cell suspension to 2x105 cells/mL in a certain volume
If detached: add fresh medium (37ºC) on top of the trypsin
Place the flask with the cells in the incubator

data.text_p1: How would you subcultivate the cells by replacing the medium if your cells are in a 125 ml erlenmeyer flask in 20 mL, the concentration of the cell suspension is 1.000.000 cells/mL, and you want to prepare 10 mL at 200.000 cells/mL in a T25 flask?

choices.answer: Take 10 mL of the  flask in a tube, centrifuge it, resuspend the pellet of cells in 10 mL of fresh medium and transfer it to a 125 mL erlenmeyer flask.

choices.answer: Take 5 mL of the  flask in a tube, centrifuge it, resuspend the pellet of cells in 10 mL of fresh medium and transfer it to a 125 mL erlenmeyer flask.
choices.bad_answer_special_text: Bad answer : please reread your notes or check your calculation

choices.answer: Take 2 mL of the  flask in a tube, centrifuge it, resuspend the pellet of cells in 10 mL of fresh medium and transfer it to a 125 mL erlenmeyer flask.

menu_main_items.title: Both adherent cells and cells in suspension

data.text_p1: How does the medium look like?

choices.answer: Still good
choices.bad_answer_special_text: Bad answer : please reread your notes

choices.answer: Partially saturated
choices.bad_answer_special_text: Bad answer : please reread your notes

choices.answer: Saturated

data.badAnswerText: Bad answer : please reread your notes
data.goodAnswerText: Explanation: Na₂HCO₃ and CO₂ need to be balanced in the medium so that pH stays neutral (pH 7=red). When the number of cells increases, the amount of CO₂ increases, too, due to their respiration. That shifts the balance to H+ production, decreasing the pH of the medium (yellow).  H₂O + CO₂ + NaHCO₃ ⟷ H⁺ + Na⁺ + 2HCO₃₋

data.text_p1: What does it mean if you have a sudden turn of color to intense yellow in your medium?

choices.answer: Cells should be fine. It is a normal adjustment of pH inside the incubator
choices.bad_answer_special_text: Bad answer : please reread your notes

choices.answer: Cells should be fine. Yellow color only means that the pH has decreased due to normal cell respiration
choices.bad_answer_special_text: Bad answer : please reread your notes

choices.answer: Cells may not be fine. There may be a contamination inside the flask

data.badAnswerText: Bad answer : please re read your notes
data.goodAnswerText: Sudden acidity of the medium indicate the presence of more living organisms than just the cell line. The release of CO₂ increases in great proportion due to the respiration of the cells and the contaminants and it leads to an intense yellow color of the medium.

data.text_p1: Regarding contamination, choose the right answer:

choices.answer: Cells can get multiple types of contaminations at the same time.
choices.bad_answer_special_text: Bad answer : please reread your notes

choices.answer: Cells can get multiple types of contaminations but only one at a time
choices.bad_answer_special_text: Bad answer : please reread your notes

choices.answer: Cells can only get contaminations of bacteria and yeast but only one at a time
choices.bad_answer_special_text: Bad answer : please reread your notes

choices.answer: Cells can only get contaminations of fungi and viruses but only one at a time
choices.bad_answer_special_text: Bad answer : please reread your notes

data.badAnswerText: Bad answer : please reread your notes
data.goodAnswerText: Most microscopic organisms love complete medium and they can all contaminate at the same time

data.text_p1: Do you have a contamination? Match the contamination type with the right picture, if applicable

possible_answers.text: No contamination but cells are dying

data.badAnswerText: Bad answer, at least one picture is bad labelled
data.goodAnswerText: All pictures were matched with the correct label

data.text_p1: How will you proceed if you have a bacteria/yeast/fungi contamination? More than one answer may be correct

answers.text: I’d discard the cells and disinfect the incubator if bacteria or yeast are in he flask, but I’ll only change the medium in case of fungi contamination since they are big and easy to remove
I’d discard my cells and everybody else’s and disinfect the incubator
I’d discard my cells and disinfect the incubator and cabinets. The rest of cells will go to a quarantine incubator
I’d discard the medium if I see turbidity or any kind of contamination signs inside it

data.badAnswerText: Bad answer : please reread your notes
data.goodAnswerText: Aerosols of all the contaminants from inside and outside the flask may contaminate the incubator/cabinet and infect other people’s flasks. Everybody should be aware of a contamination on anyone’s cells in order to keep a close eye on their cells. Medium would normally also be contaminated if cells are but it won’t show signs of contamination until much later since it is kept at 4ºC, a temperature that decreases growth of any living organism.
